Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(2) Summary

Microservices are making services individually evolvable by using self-contained capabilities that can be created, deployed, and modified in a standalone way. They do this by only being usable through their own API and by only using other services through their APIs. In order for microservices to reach their full potential it is important to conceive and manage them, and thus their API, as a product. Such a microservice product can be called a microproduct and it represents a digital building block in the services that are the foundation for an organization's digital transformation. We dive into why this matters and what it means to move from a microservices to a microproduct mindset. This move encompasses API product management and a full lifecycle perspective for each individual microservice.



Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(9) Consumption Matters

  • Modular end-products can be more easily adapted/changed
  • Modular end-products allow for mass customization
  • Modular end-products allow for experimentation and (better) tolerate failure
  • Modular end-products make it easier to out-source/in-source
  • Modular end-products allow for better market coverage


Products and Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(10) Modern Products Need Platforms



Products and Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(11) Platform SCM: A Cautionary Tale

  • Many organizations are adding social features to their products/experiences
  • Protecting against trolling, spam, and harassment is important
  • Building robust social protections is not trivial
  • Organizations end up with dependencies in their value chains


The Three Platform Types

Outline (The Three Platform Types)

  1. Products and Platforms [7]
  2. The Three Platform Types [6]
  3. Getting Microservices to Work: Microproducts [5]
  4. Conclusions [2]
The Three Platform Types Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(13) What is a Platform?

  • Something to be used as a foundation
  • Providing building blocks for building new things
  • Platforms provide raw materials … They contain products!
  • Platforms are being built on … They create products!
  • Platforms need to be consumable … They are products!


The Three Platform Types Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(14) The Platform Talk



The Three Platform Types Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(15) Business Platforms

  • Providing means of connection instead of means of production
  • The main product of a pure platform business is connectivity
  • Few business are pure platform businesses
  • Most businesses can augment their products with platformy connectivity


The Three Platform Types Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(16) API Platforms

  • API platforms provide consumable digital building blocks
  • Many businesses are creating APIs as product features>
  • API platforms expose what product features are available
  • API platforms don't prescribe how to use product features


The Three Platform Types Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(17) Developer Platforms

  • Developer platforms provide support for consuming digital building blocks
  • Trading assumptions about consumption for better Developer Experience (DX)
  • Wide range of assumptions from programming languages to specific development environments


The Three Platform Types Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(18) Balancing the Three Platform Types

  • Business Platforms [Business Platforms (1)] are about the why of interacting with your organization
  • API Platforms [API Platforms (1)] are about what interactions your organization provides
  • Developer Platforms [Developer Platforms (1)] support how to develop software interacting with your organization
  • It's a good idea to clearly separate and answer these questions

Getting Microservices to Work: Microproducts Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(20) Microservice Definition

A microservice is an independently deployable component of bounded scope that supports interoperability through message-based communication. Microservice architecture is a style of engineering highly automated, evolvable software systems made up of capability-aligned microservices. (Irakli Nadareishvili, Ronnie Mitra, Matt McLarty, and Mike Amundsen, Microservice Architecture, O'Reilly, 2016)



Getting Microservices to Work: Microproducts Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(21) Microproducts



Getting Microservices to Work: Microproducts Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(22) API Products? Product APIs? API-as-a-Product?

  • Most APIs are not the main way how a product is consumed
  • Increasingly, products provide APIs as product features
  • Treating APIs as a product helps with API quality and consumption


Getting Microservices to Work: Microproducts Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(23) When to treat an API as a Product

  1. Have The Platform Talk [The Platform Talk (1)] to clarify the why/what/how
  2. Identify/classify APIs how they align with strategic capabilities
  3. Differentiating external and everything else usually isn't good enough
  4. Support different API lifecycles depending on classification


Getting Microservices to Work: Microproducts Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(24) How to treat an API as a Product

  • Products are designed for markets
  • Make product management and product marketing part of your API strategy
  • Classical 4P: Product, price, place, and promotion
  • Shimizu's 4C: Commodity, cost, channel, and communication
  • Lauterborn's 4C: Consumer, cost, convenience, and communication


Conclusions

Outline (Conclusions)

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products

(26) Why ≫ What ≫ How

  • Why are you using APIs?
    • Focus on valuable digital building blocks
  • What are the APIs you are building?
    • Focus on building the right APIs
  • How are you building the APIs?
    • Focus on building them in the right way


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Microproducts: Managing Microservices as API Products
